section_overview: Classic New England summer showing with efficient ring flow and mountain-weather mood swings. Multiple rings run in parallel, so plan by ring cluster and live off in-gate texts. Warm-up rings are orderly but surge before eq and derby cards—catch a quiet window right after a drag for the truest read. The jog strip is clearly posted near the hunter complex: numbers front and center, quick forward trot, and a microfiber towel in your pocket. Vendor row carries week-save essentials (gloves, spur straps, studs, braiding fixes) and quick snacks between trips. Stabling is laid out for straight shots to schooling areas—keep fans secured, trunks flush, and ring bags pre-packed for fast turnarounds. Footing is modern all-weather with frequent drags and water; it rides best once it’s packed, so pop a vertical early to set your canter. Expect cool mornings, pop-up showers, and bright sun an hour later—layers and spare gloves live in the ring bag for a reason.

section_spotlight.title: Quick Hits for HITS Vermont
bullets: Warm-up cadence: light right after a drag—build your last oxer then for the best read.
Ring clusters: group classes by in-gate to cut cart miles and missed calls.
Jog strip kit: towel, hoof oil, alcohol spritz; numbers visible and a forward trot.
Footing feel: improves as it packs—set canter with a simple vertical early.
Call-ups: monitor in-gate texts and stage two trips out with a spare crop and holes punched.
Stabling ops: fans secured, trunks flush, ring bag stocked (studs, extra gloves, towel).
Weather swing: layers in the bag; expect cool AMs, sun, and surprise showers.
Derby/GP days: earlier schooling wins—warm-ups fill quickly before big cards.
Vendor row timing: hit it between drags, not at last call, for zero-stress fixes.
Team roles: one tack runner, one ring runner; radios save steps and scratches.
